title: 114_s1776
content: The "Tribal Infrastructure and Roads Enhancement and Safety Act" or the "TIRES Act" defines the term "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior. This Act applies categorical exclusions to certain tribal transportation facilities. The "Tribal Transportation Safety Project" is defined as a project eligible for funding under section 202 of title 23, United States Code, that corrects hazardous road locations, addresses highway safety problems, and includes intersection safety improvements, pavement widening, and installation of warning devices like rumble strips. The curr_chunk discusses various safety improvements that can be made, including skid-resistant surfaces, pedestrian/bicyclist safety enhancements, railway-highway grade crossing features, traffic enforcement activities, traffic calming measures, and roadside hazard elimination. The curr_chunk outlines safety improvement projects such as highway signage upgrades, emergency vehicle priority control systems, high crash potential warning devices, transportation safety planning, safety data analysis, and emergency communications planning. The curr_chunk focuses on safety measures in work zones, including guardrails, crash attenuators, wildlife crash prevention, yellow-green signs at crossings, and improvements on high-risk rural roads. The curr_chunk outlines various safety improvements for roads, including geometric enhancements, road safety audits, infrastructure upgrades, truck parking facilities, systemic safety measures, vehicle-to-infrastructure communication equipment, and pedestrian hybrid beacons. The curr_chunk discusses new categorical exclusions for reviewing projects eligible for assistance under section 202 of title 23, United States Code. The Secretary will review existing categorical exclusions and tribal transportation safety projects. The Secretary will identify tribal transportation safety projects meeting categorical exclusion requirements and propose a rule for these exclusions within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Transportation will provide technical assistance for carrying out tribal transportation safety projects. Reviews of these projects must be completed promptly under applicable federal laws. The Secretary of Transportation will take final action on tribal transportation safety project applications or provide a schedule for review within 45 days of making decisions under the National Environmental Policy Act. The Secretary of Transportation will make decisions on tribal transportation safety project applications within 45 days under the National Environmental Policy Act. If the deadline is not met, the Secretary will notify the Committee on Indian Affairs. Extensions of 30 days may be granted with notice to the Indian tribe. If the deadline for tribal transportation safety project applications under the National Environmental Policy Act is not met, the Secretary of Transportation will notify the Committee on Indian Affairs and provide a detailed explanation for the delay. SEC. 4. PROGRAMMATIC AGREEMENTS FOR CATEGORICAL EXCLUSIONS. The Secretary will establish programmatic agreements with Indian tribes to streamline environmental reviews for projects under section 202 of title 23, US Code. These agreements may allow tribes to determine if a project is exempt from certain environmental assessments and require tribes to have the capacity to fulfill agency responsibilities. The programmatic agreements with Indian tribes under section 202 of title 23, US Code, outline the responsibilities of the tribe for making categorical exclusion determinations, quality control, and quality assurance. The agreements also allow the Secretary to monitor compliance and the tribe to take corrective action, with provisions for amendments, termination, and public availability. The programmatic agreements with Indian tribes under section 202 of title 23, US Code outline the responsibilities of the tribe for making categorical exclusion determinations, quality control, and quality assurance. The agreements also have a term of not more than 5 years, with an option for renewal based on a review by the Secretary of the performance of the Indian tribe. Passed the Senate on December 10, 2016, S. 1776 is an act aimed at improving tribal road safety and addressing other related purposes.
